FieldValue.Value: Food allergy and hypersensitivity in children.

Finnish Medical Society Duodecim. Food allergy and hypersensitivity in children. In: EBM Guidelines. Evidence-Based Medicine [Internet]. Helsinki, Finland: Wiley Interscience. John Wiley & Sons; 2010 Dec 1 [Various].

This is the current release of the guideline.

This guideline updates a previous version: Finnish Medical Society Duodecim. Paediatric food hypersensitivity and allergy. In: EBM Guidelines. Evidence-Based Medicine [Internet]. Helsinki, Finland: Wiley Interscience. John Wiley & Sons; 2008 Apr 10 [Various]. [13 references]

Food hypersensitivity and allergy
Risk Assessment
Allergy and Immunology
Family Practice
Internal Medicine
Preventive Medicine
Health Care Providers

Evidence-Based Medicine Guidelines collect, summarize, and update the core clinical knowledge essential in general practice. The guidelines also describe the scientific evidence underlying the given recommendations.
Children at risk for and with known food hypersensitivity and allergy

Prevention

  1. Identification of risk groups and preventative measures
  2. Preventative measures that may be beneficial:
    • Exclusive breast feeding for at least 4 to 6 months
    • Probiotic bacteria (the effects are strain-specific)

Note: The guideline developers considered but did not recommend maternal dietary antigen avoidance during pregnancy/lactation or the delaying of the introduction of solids beyond 4–6 months of age to reduce the risk of allergy.

Diagnosis/Evaluation

  1. Evaluation of signs and symptoms of food allergy:
    • Cutaneous manifestations (e.g., atopic eczema)
    • Intestinal symptoms
    • Respiratory tract symptoms
  2. Diagnosis of food allergy:
    • Elimination and challenge tests (avoid testing older children unless strong indication)
    • Allergy history
    • Suspicion of previous anaphylactic reaction

Note: The guideline developers considered but did not recommend diagnosis as a result of positive skin prick tests, the presence of specific IgE antibodies, or a patch/epicutaneous test.

Treatment/Management

  1. Avoidance of foods that cause symptoms
  2. Alternative nutrients if elimination of important food groups; dietitian's care is preferred
  3. Administration of antihistamines for allergic reaction; an adrenaline auto-injector for serious systemic reaction
  4. Follow-up:
    • Elimination of foods of no nutritional significance
    • Growth monitoring
    • Vaccinations according to normal program
    • Encouragement of family to expand and rationalise the diet; use of a symptom diary
    • Re-evaluation at 5 years (no elimination diets at school-age except with an established diagnosis)

• Incidence of signs and symptoms of food allergy
  • Diagnostic accuracy
  • Effects of treatment

Field.Name: Methods Used to Collect/Select the Evidence

FieldValue.Value: Hand-searches of Published Literature (Primary Sources)
Hand-searches of Published Literature (Secondary Sources)
Searches of Electronic Databases

Field.Name: Description of Methods Used to Collect/Select the Evidence

FieldValue.Value:
The evidence reviewed was collected from the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. In addition, the Cochrane Library and medical journals were searched specifically for original publications.

Comprehensive and systematic searches were conducted for all topics for which the Finnish Medical Society Duodecim produces national guidelines. As most of our evidence summaries are based on systematic reviews (of which Cochrane reviews are the most important), the search dates are available in the original reviews.

Specific Search Strategy

The evidence reviewed was updated with a current care search date of March 31, 2008, with the last comprehensive search on November 11, 2007.
Not stated

FieldValue.Value: Weighting According to a Rating Scheme (Scheme Given)

Field.Name: Rating Scheme for the Strength of the Evidence

FieldValue.Value:
Classification of the Quality of Evidence

Code Quality of Evidence Definition
A High Further research is very unlikely to change confidence in the estimate of effect.
  • Several high-quality studies with consistent results
  • In special cases: one large, high-quality multi-centre trial
B Moderate Further research is likely to have an important impact on confidence in the estimate of effect and may change the estimate.
  • One high-quality study
  • Several studies with some limitations
C Low Further research is very likely to have an important impact on confidence in the estimate of effect and is likely to change the estimate.
  • One or more studies with severe limitations
D Very Low Any estimate of effect is very uncertain.
  • Expert opinion
  • No direct research evidence
  • One or more studies with very severe limitations

Field.Name: Description of Method of Guideline Validation

FieldValue.Value: Not stated

The levels of evidence [A-D] supporting the recommendations are defined at the end of the "Major Recommendations" field.

  • Prolonged elimination diets should not be started unless clearly indicated. There is little reliable evidence on the benefits of long-term elimination diets, for example, in the treatment of atopic dermatitis (Hoare, Li Wan Po, & Williams, 2000).
  • An elimination diet started before school age should either be stopped before the child goes to school or proper grounds must be given for its continuation.
  • Food hypersensitivity refers to both food allergy and food intolerance (Johansson et al., 2001).
  • In food allergy, it is possible to demonstrate an immunological mechanism in addition to the symptoms. This is usually done with a skin prick test or by determining food specific immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies in the serum.

Epidemiology

  • As many as half of all parents with children aged less than 1-2 years associate some of their child's symptoms with food; however, the majority of these suspicions disappear with time (Eggesbo et al., 1999; Venter et al., 2006).
  • In a survey of school children, 24% reported to have, or to have had at some stage, a food allergy (Csonka et al., 2000).

Prevention

  • In order to prevent a disease from developing one should be able to reliably identify the appropriate risk group as well as to have access to effective preventative measures. No measures with a preventative effect are available for food allergy.
  • Maternal dietary antigen avoidance during pregnancy (Kramer & Kakuma, 2006) [C] or lactation (Kramer & Kakuma, 2006) [D] has no preventative effect (Greer et al., 2008; Høst et al., 2008).
  • There is conflicting evidence as regards the effect of breast feeding on the development of atopic disease and food allergy. Exclusive breast feeding for 4–6 months may provide some protection against the development of atopic eczema (Greer et al., 2008).
  • There is no evidence that delaying the introduction of solids to beyond 4–6 months of age reduces the risk of allergy (Greer et al., 2008).
  • Probiotic bacteria have reduced the risk of atopic eczema and IgE-mediated allergic disease, and their use may be beneficial. However, the effects are strain-specific (Lee, Seto, & Bielory, 2008; Kukkonen et al., 2007); the most extensively studied strain is Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG.

Causes of Food Allergy

  • In principle, any food that contains proteins can cause allergy.
  • In infants, the most common causative agents are milk, egg and wheat. School-age children with pollen allergy may develop symptoms to fresh fruits and root vegetables via cross reactions.

Cow's Milk, Wheat, Barley and Rye Allergy

  • Clinically the most significant allergies (Räsänen & Ylönen, 1992).
  • Encountered in very young children; rarely after pre-school age
  • Symptoms caused by these nutritionally important foods usually appear in infancy a few weeks after the food has been introduced to the child's diet.
  • The diagnosis should be confirmed with a supervised elimination-challenge test.
  • See the Finnish Medical Society Duodecim guideline "Cow's milk allergy."

Birch Pollen Allergy

  • Different plant allergens share a similar structure, and many fresh fruits, vegetables and nuts can cause symptoms in the oral mucosa, such as itching and tingling (known as "oral allergy syndrome").
  • Tree nuts (e.g., hazel nuts and walnuts) and almonds are common causes of symptoms. Root vegetables capable of causing symptoms include potato, carrot, celery and parsnip. Other vegetables and fruit often acting as allergens are apple, pear, peach, kiwi fruit, plum, mango, tomato and sweet pepper. Occasionally spices can also cause symptoms, including mustard, caraway, turmeric, ginger and cinnamon.
  • Preparation of fruit and vegetables (cooking and freezing) removes their allergenicity making it possible for the majority of those allergic to birch pollen to consume them.
  • After pre-school age, the avoidance of allergens should be based on symptom emergence. Due to cross-reactions, false-positive results are common in skin prick and specific IgE antibody tests, but they correlate poorly with the symptoms and are therefore not recommended.

Other Allergens Causing Pollen-Food Cross Reactions

  • Peanuts, soya, fish, shellfish, banana, avocado

Food Intolerance

  • Enzyme deficiency
    • The most common form is lactase deficiency, which leads to lactose intolerance. The symptoms do not emerge until school age or adulthood.
  • Biogenic amines that release histamine
    • Strawberry, citrus fruit, chocolate, tomato

Anaphylactic Reaction

  • In theory, any food can act as the causative agent.
    • In children: milk, wheat and egg
    • In children and adults: nuts, seeds, peanuts, fish, shellfish

Central Questions

  • Signs and symptoms: what were the observed symptoms and when did they start, and have the symptoms recurred? What was the timing of the onset of symptoms in relation to food exposure?
  • Current diet; has some food already been eliminated and what are the reasons for the elimination?
  • Courses of antibiotics (effect on intestinal symptoms)
  • Skin care (use of moisturising lotions and topical corticosteroids)
  • Breast feeding (duration of exclusive breast feeding, total duration of breast feeding, the first contact with infant formulas, introduction of complementary foods, any particular maternal diets)
  • Family history of allergies
  • Smoking (includes outside, in the car, at the grandparents' house etc.)
  • Could the patient have a metabolic disorder, coeliac disease or lactose intolerance?
  • Growth chart (height, weight, head circumference)

Infant (<1 year)

  • History
    • Do symptoms warrant further investigations or are they part of normal infancy? Infants are individual and their temperaments vary, which is reflected in the child's contentment, happiness, crying and sleep-wake pattern.
    • The consideration of confounding factors is particularly important.
  • The foods that were introduced most recently may be eliminated as a trial and the child observed for the development of symptoms. If this is beneficial, the eliminated foods are reintroduced one at a time.
  • It is particularly important that no new foods are added randomly at the time of diagnostic work up.
  • Any diet that has no effect on the symptoms must be stopped.

An Older Child

  • Food-induced symptoms are unlikely.
  • Cross reactions in birch pollen allergy: see above
  • A rash that heals in the summer is not likely to be caused by food allergy (Hoare, Li Wan Po & Williams, 2000).

Symptoms of Food Allergy

Cutaneous Manifestations

  • Urticaria, redness of the skin (immediate reactions), exacerbation of atopic eczema (delayed reaction)
  • A food substance is often found to be an exacerbating factor in severe atopic eczema in an infant.
  • Atopic dermatitis may be exacerbated by many factors, including dry winter air, stress and infections. A relapsing-remitting pattern is common, which is challenging in infancy when many new foods are introduced.

Intestinal Symptoms

  • Abdominal pain, vomiting, changes in stool consistency, persistent crying and restlessness are delayed reactions that are very difficult to interpret. The frequency of bowel motions varies greatly between individuals. For example, a normal pattern for an infant may be a bowel movement 10 times a day or once a week (provided that the child is well and developing normally).
  • Of gastrointestinal symptoms, the most obvious one is contact allergy around the mouth and lips which appears almost immediately after ingestion and is therefore easy to connect with the offending food (tomato, citrus fruit and apple in birch pollen allergy).
  • All changes in the diet can cause temporary changes in bowel function, which is a normal phenomenon.

Respiratory Tract Symptoms

  • Rhinitis, itchy eyes, sneezing and dyspnoea are rare.
    • They are usually associated with a severe systemic reaction with signs of urticaria and anaphylaxis.
  • IgE-mediated symptoms usually occur within minutes and no later than within 1–2 hours, whereas hours to days may pass before delayed, cell-mediated symptoms occur.
  • It is extremely difficult to associate delayed intestinal reactions and exacerbations of atopic eczema with a particular food. A double-blind food challenge may be of use in the diagnosis.

Other Symptoms

  • There is no evidence supporting an association between food (food hypersensitivity) and migraine, arthritis, cystitis or nephritis.

Diagnosis of Food Allergy

  • As a basic rule, testing of older children for food allergy should be avoided unless there is a strong suspicion (Vandenplas et al., 2007).
  • Elimination and challenge tests form the basis of diagnosis (see Picture 1 in the original guideline document). See the Finnish Medical Society Duodecim guideline "Cow's milk allergy." For nutritionally important foods (milk and wheat in young children) a more formal elimination–challenge test should be carried out, for example as follows:
    • The suspected food(s) is totally eliminated from the diet (for 1–2 weeks).
    • The development/resolution of symptoms is recorded in a symptom diary.
    • An improvement or disappearance of symptoms supports the presence of food allergy, but it is not diagnostic. The food needs to be reintroduced (challenge).
    • A small amount of the food is reintroduced to the diet and as long as the child remains asymptomatic the amount is increased gradually to the normal (age-adjusted) daily amount. See the Finnish Medical Society Duodecim guideline "Cow's milk allergy."
    • Symptoms usually reappear no later than 1–2 days following the reintroduction of the food (symptom diary), provided that the amounts consumed are adequate. Symptoms that appear after 5 days are not indicative of an allergy.
  • Immediate reactions can be diagnosed with the aid of a detailed history. There is no need to test for foods that are nutritionally less important, but they can be eliminated from the diet and reintroduced at a later stage.
  • Suspicion of anaphylactic reactions caused by food: if there is a clear suspicion of an anaphylactic reaction, the patient must not be asked to retry the suspected food at home; the decision concerning allergen challenge should always be made by a specialist.
  • Positive skin prick tests or the presence of specific IgE antibodies are not sufficient for a diagnosis. Immunoglobulin A (IgA) and immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies can be detected in everyone and are not useful in diagnostics.
  • Pre-school and older children can typically have positive results to skin prick and blood tests, which are of no clinical significance.
  • A patch or epicutaneous test is a method used in scientific research with selected patients in specialist settings. According to current knowledge this is not a sufficiently reliable test.

Treatment

  • Food allergy is treated by avoiding food that causes symptoms. The extent of avoidance depends on the severity of the symptoms; if the symptoms are mild there is no need to totally eliminate the offending food. Otherwise, an attempt should be made to provide a normal age-appropriate diet.
  • If nutritionally important foods (milk, cereals) are to be eliminated, it must be ensured that alternative nutrients are provided, and a dietitian should be involved in the care.
  • The aim is normal growth and development.
  • The majority of children with food allergy will experience accidental exposure to the offending food. The parents must be instructed to administer antihistamines as first aid for allergic reactions. If the child has had a serious systemic reaction, he/she must carry an adrenaline auto-injector the use of which has been demonstrated.

Prognosis of Food Allergy

  • Early childhood food allergies resolve during the first few years of life. Half of children with cow's milk allergy will tolerate milk at the age of 2 years and 75% at the age of 3 years. Cereal and egg allergies also resolve in the majority of children by the time they reach school age.

Follow-up and Organisation of Care

  • Individual foods which are of no nutritional significance can be eliminated in primary care if the causal relationship of food to symptoms is clear. Elimination and reintroduction can be carried out at home whilst keeping a symptom diary.
  • No adequate studies are available on how these children should be followed up. Clinical experience therefore dictates the follow up routines.
  • Indications for a referral to a specialist
    • A small infant with widespread eczema or worsening symptoms
    • A small infant with difficult or perplexing symptoms, and the parents are convinced of food allergy
    • An infant in whom food allergy to an important nutrient is suspected (milk, wheat)
    • Failure to thrive
    • Continual self-imposed limitations to diet
  • In primary care
    • The growth of a child on an elimination diet is monitored with growth charts.
    • Vaccinations are given according to the normal programme. Allergy to egg does not prevent vaccination unless the child has had an anaphylactic reaction to egg. See the Finnish Medical Society Duodecim guideline "Vaccinations."
    • The family is encouraged to expand and rationalise the diet towards a normal diet.
    • The child's diet should be re-evaluated at 5 years of age at the latest: is the avoidance of certain foods based on an elimination–challenge test? Should a specialist re-evaluate the situation?
    • Target: all elimination diets at school-age should be based on an established diagnosis.

Related Resources

Refer to the original guideline document for related evidence, including Cochrane reviews and other evidence summaries.

Definitions:

Classification of the Quality of Evidence

Code Quality of Evidence Definition
A High Further research is very unlikely to change confidence in the estimate of effect.
  • Several high-quality studies with consistent results
  • In special cases: one large, high-quality multi-centre trial
B Moderate Further research is likely to have an important impact on confidence in the estimate of effect and may change the estimate.
  • One high-quality study
  • Several studies with some limitations
C Low Further research is very likely to have an important impact on confidence in the estimate of effect and is likely to change the estimate.
  • One or more studies with severe limitations
D Very Low Any estimate of effect is very uncertain.
  • Expert opinion
  • No direct research evidence
  • One or more studies with very severe limitations

Field.Name: Type of Evidence Supporting the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: Concise summaries of scientific evidence attached to the individual guidelines are the unique feature of the Evidence-Based Medicine Guidelines. The evidence summaries allow the clinician to judge how well-founded the treatment recommendations are. The type of supporting evidence is identified and graded for select recommendations (see the "Major Recommendations" field).
